Chapter 7, Part 6: Distinguishing the Noble Ones, also called the Factors of Awakening.
How many kinds are there?
What are their names and meanings?
Verse:
The factors of awakening are thirty-seven, namely the four establishments of mindfulness and so forth;
Awakening refers to the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising. Because they accord with this, they are called factors.
Discussion:

The sÅ«tras say there are thirty-seven factors of awakening, namely the four establishments of mindfulness, four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path.

The knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising is called awakening. Based on the distinctions of the one who awakens, three kinds of enlightenment are established: first, the enlightenment of the Å›rÄvakas, second, the enlightenment of the pratyekabuddhas, and third, the unsurpassed enlightenment. Because all ignorance and sleepiness are permanently eliminated, and because one truly knows that what should be done has been done and will not be done again, these two are called awakening.
The thirty-seven factors that assist in the quest for enlightenment are so called because they all assist in the quest for enlightenment.
Are the natures of these thirty-seven distinct?
No, it is not so.
What is the case?
A verse says:
In reality, they are only ten, namely, discernment, zeal, samÄdhi, faith,
memory, joy, letting go, pliancy, and morality and investigation.
The treatise says:

Although the names of these factors that assist in enlightenment are thirty-seven, in reality they are only ten, namely, discernment, zeal, samÄdhi, faith,ğŸ”½memory, joy, letting go, pliancy, and morality and investigation.

The four foundations of mindfulness, the faculty of discernment, the power of discernment, the factor of discernment that assists in enlightenment, and right views all have discernment as their nature.
The four right efforts, the faculty of zeal, the power of zeal, the factor of zeal that assists in enlightenment, and right effort all have zeal as their nature.
The four bases of supernatural powers, the faculty of samÄdhi, the power of samÄdhi, the factor of samÄdhi that assists in enlightenment, and right samÄdhi all have samÄdhi as their nature.
The faculty of faith and the power of faith both have faith as their nature.
The faculty of mindfulness, the power of mindfulness, the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness, and right mindfulness all have mindfulness as their essence.
The factor of enlightenment of joy has joy as its essence.ğŸ”½The factor of enlightenment of equanimity has the equanimity subsumed in the aggregate of formation as its essence.
The factor of enlightenment of pliancy has pliancy as its essence.
Right speech, right action, and right livelihood all have morality as their essence.
Right thought has investigation as its essence.
Thus the factors of enlightenment are actually only ten.

The first five are precisely the five faculties of faith, etc. They are divided into thirty due to differences in objects, etc. Adding joy, equanimity, pliancy, morality, and investigation, with the category of morality divided into three, they then form seven, and together with the previous they form thirty-seven kinds.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters say there are eleven, because bodily action and verbal action are not mixed, morality is divided into two, and the other nine are the same as before.
The three of mindfulness, etc. have no specific affiliation. How are they alone said to be wisdom, effort, and concentration?
Verse:
The four establishments of mindfulness and the four right efforts,ğŸ”½the four bases of supernatural power, according to their predominance,
The four foundations of mindfulness, right effort, and the four bases of supernatural power are said to be wisdom, zeal, and concentration, and in reality they are all wholesome practices.
The treatise says:

The three categories of wholesome dharmas such as the four foundations of mindfulness actually universally include all wholesome practices, but following the dominant wholesome roots in each category, they are respectively said to be wisdom, zeal, and concentration.
Why is wisdom called the foundation of mindfulness?
Because wisdom is made to abide by the power of mindfulness.
Why is zeal called right effort?
Because in the stage of cultivating the abandonment of correct practice, this zeal is able to abandon laziness.
Or it is called right exertion, because in the correct control and encouragement of body, speech, and mind, it is the most excellent.
Why are the four bases of supernatural power called bases of supernatural power?
Because they are the support of all marvelous virtues.
Why are faith, etc. called faculties and powers?
Because they are dominant and difficult to subdue.
Why are these five first called faculties and later called powers?
The five faculties are distinguished as prior and subsequent on the basis of their weakness and strength.

Also, they are distinguished as prior and subsequent on the basis of being able to be overcome and not being able to be overcome, because faith, etc., in the stage of weakness are weak in power and are overcome by their opposites, while in the stage of strength they are the opposite of this and are therefore called powers.
What is the meaning of the factors that contribute to enlightenment?
The meaning of enlightenment is called the factors that contribute to enlightenment.
If that is so, then the factors that contribute to enlightenment should be only one.
No, mindfulness, etc., are parts of the discernment of dharmas and all contribute to the discernment of dharmas. They are named according to the most important.
Or, the meaning of the factors that contribute to enlightenment is that they are parts of enlightenment.
If that is so, then you should admit that the factors that contribute to enlightenment are only six.
No, the discernment of dharmas is both enlightenment and a factor that contributes to enlightenment, while the remaining seven are only factors that contribute to enlightenment and not enlightenment.
What is the meaning of the factors of the path?
The meaning of seeking a support is called the factors of the path.
If that is so, then the factors of the path should be only one.
No, the remaining seven are parts of right view and all contribute to right view. They are named according to the most important.
Or the meaning of â€œlimb of the pathâ€ is â€œthat which is a branch of the path.â€
If this is so, then you should admit that the limbs of the path are only seven.
This is not so, because right view is both the path and a limb of the path, while the remaining seven are only limbs of the path.
In what states are the members of the path increased?
The verse states:
In the state of initial practice, in accordance with decisive discernment, and in the states of cultivation and the path of insight,
The seven categories such as mindfulness are to be known as gradually increasing.
The treatise states:

In the state of initial practice, mindfulness is said to be increased. This means that in this state, in order to stop delusions, by the power of mindfulness, one is able to clearly understand the specific and common characteristics of objects such as the body, destroy the two kinds of ignorance, and the function of wisdom is superior.

In the state of the heat stage, right effort is said to be increased. This means that in this state, one sees the faults of saá¹ƒsÄra and the merits of nirvÄá¹‡a, and is thus able to courageously give rise to diligent effort, not fall into saá¹ƒsÄra, and quickly enter nirvÄá¹‡a. The function of effort is superior.

In the state of summit, the four foundations of mindfulness are said to be predominant, because in this state one is able to control the mind and direct it toward the state of nonretrogression, and one is never lacking in the power of faith, etc., because the power of samÄdhi is superior.

In the state of receptivity, the five faculties are said to be predominant, because in this state one forever puts an end to evil destinies and never retrogresses into them, and one quickly enters the family of the saints, and the meaning of predominance is fulfilled, because the meaning of faculty is superior.
In the state of the highest worldly point, the five powers are said to be predominant, because in this state one is not bent by the passions, and the meaning of power is superior.
Even though this is also true of the state of receptivity, still it is not certain, and therefore it is not mentioned.
Or, in this state one is not bent by any other ordinary man, and therefore the meaning of power is predominant in this state.
In the state of the path of cultivation, the seven factors that is, members of enlightenment are said to be predominant, because in this state they are superior in assisting enlightenment.
Or, in this state one cuts off the nine categories of passions and is enlightened many times, and therefore the meaning of the factors that is, members of enlightenment is predominant.
The path of insight is replete with all the meanings of the path, and for that reason it is said that the members of the path are increased.
That is, it is called the path because it is the support for seeking and because it is able to proceed to the other shore.

In the state of the path of insight, these two meanings are most excellent, because in the state of the path of insight, holy wisdom is born for the first time and is superior in seeking the meaning of the truths as they really are.
Also, in this state one does not arouse a temporary mind and is superior in being able to proceed quickly to the other shore.
In the scriptures, the seven members are mentioned first and the eight members are mentioned later, but this is not the order of cultivation.
Others establish the order of the members of the path in the following way.

When a practitioner first uses the power of wisdom, he thoroughly understands the specific and common characteristics of objects such as the body, and he initiates the arising of many good states, just as one with eyes leads a group of blind people. For this reason, the four foundations of mindfulness are mentioned first.

Having become established in the four foundations of mindfulness, one is able to initiate the abandonment of evil and the cultivation of good. Therefore, the four right efforts are mentioned in the second place.

By the power of right effort, faults are reduced and merits increase in the continuity of mind, and one is able to cultivate superior samÄdhi. Therefore, the bases of spiritual power are said to be third.
Relying on superior samÄdhi, one causes faith and so on to be dominant conditions for supramundane dharmas. Therefore, the five faculties are said to be fourth.
Once the meaning of the faculties is established, one is unable to be bent by evil destinies, evil karma, and afflictions. Therefore, the five powers are said to be fifth.

Once the meaning of the powers is accomplished, one is able to realize the objects of the four noble truths as they really are without doubt. Therefore, the seven factors of enlightenment are said to be sixth.

Having already realized the objects of the four noble truths as they really are, one becomes disgusted with saá¹ƒsÄra and delights in seeking nirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, the factors of the path are said to be seventh.
As for the order of each of these, one should seek it by properly contemplating the sÅ«tras and Å›Ästras.
In this treatise, we analyze the characteristics of dharmas, and there is no need to trouble ourselves with the principle of order.
Among the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, how many are only pure and how many are of two kinds?
The verse says:
The seven factors of enlightenment and the eight factors of the path are exclusively pure;
The four, three, and five faculties and powers are both pure and impure.
The treatise says:
Among these, the seven factors of enlightenment and the eight factors of the noble path are only pure, because they are only established in the path of cultivation and the path of seeing.

That is to say, in the stage of the path of cultivation, the seven factors of enlightenment increase, and they are close to bodhi. It is said that they are the antidote to the peak of existence, therefore the essence of the factors of enlightenment is exclusively pure.
All the factors of enlightenment assist bodhi, but only these are uniquely called the factors of enlightenment, because they are the closest to the fruit of bodhi.

By this principle, it is proven that the seven factors of enlightenment should be understood as only being the antidote to the peak of existence. Taking this as the foremost, they are classified as the antidote to the lower stages, and only in the pure [factors] are they called the factors of enlightenment.
If one does not allow this, how can they not be of two kinds?
Or, among all the factors of enlightenment, the term â€œlimb of enlightenmentâ€ is established based on their proximity to enlightenment.
In the path of cultivation, the nature proximate to enlightenment is only pure, therefore the pure path of cultivation is established as having the name â€œlimb of enlightenment.â€
In the stage of the path of insight, the eight limbs of the path are superior, therefore they are exclusively pure in nature.
Although right view, etc., are also impure, they do not obtain the name â€œlimb of the noble path,â€ because the name â€œlimb of the noble pathâ€ refers to the pure path.
Also, the treatise authors allow that the factors of enlightenment are the limbs of enlightenment, and that they are explained after the limbs of enlightenment, and that they are definitely pure.
If they are explained before, then they are of two kinds.
Since the limbs of the path are explained after the limbs of enlightenment, the eight limbs of the path are exclusively pure.
The remaining are both kinds, and the meaning is already established by implication.

That is, among the factors of enlightenment, those that increase in the earlier stage also increase in power and function in the later stage, but those that increase in the later stage are not in the earlier stage.
Therefore the VibhÄá¹£Ä says:
From the stage of initial practice up to the exhaustion of production, the stage of mindfulness always increases, and so on at length.
How many of these thirty-seven exist in what stage?
Verse:
All exist in the first trance state, in the preliminary stage joy is excluded,
In the second trance state investigation is excluded, in the third and fourth two are excluded,
In the first three formless stages, morality and two are excluded,
In the desire realm and the summit of existence, the factors of enlightenment and the path are excluded.
Commentary:

All thirty-seven exist in the first trance state. In the preliminary stage, the factor of joy is excluded. Because one still harbors doubts about the dharmas of the lower stages and is unable to have confidence in them, one does not give rise to joy.

Also, when the preliminary concentration first appears, one is still unable to eliminate the defilements of the lower stages. Later, although they have already been eliminated, the type is the same as before, so when they arise, there is no joy.
Some say that all the preliminary stages and path stages all proceed with effort, so there is no meaning of joy.
In the second trance state, right conceptualization is excluded, because in that trance state there is no initial inquiry.
This is because a scripture says,
That stage is without initial inquiry, because the samÄdhi above it is tranquil.
Consequently, each of these two stages has thirty-six members.
In the third and fourth trance states, joy and initial inquiry are excluded, and each has thirty-five members.
In the first three immaterial states, morality and the three members of trance are excluded, and joy and initial inquiry are also excluded, and each has thirty-two members.
In the realm of desire and in the state of neither perception nor nonperception, the members of the path are excluded, because there is no pure path, and each has twenty-two members.
In these various stages, the members of enlightenment that are present are not fixed in number as more or less.

This is because in the various states, the latter always include the former, and it is possible for one substance to have many kinds of meanings. Consequently, there is the meaning of many kinds arising simultaneously.
However, the four foundations of mindfulness definitely do not arise simultaneously, because they are distinguished as four on the basis of their objects.
Even two kinds of discernment do not arise simultaneously, much less four kinds of discernment arising at one time.

It is impossible for a single wisdom to be divided into many according to its object, because if it is generally said to be included in the application of mindfulness to dharmas, then it definitely does not arise in a single moment with four aspects of objects.
By this principle, in the first trance state, in general there are thirty-seven, but at most only thirty-four can be present in a single moment.
In this way, in the preliminary stage and second trance state, at most only thirty-three can be present.
Between the third and fourth, at most thirty-two can be present.
In the first three formless states, at most twenty-nine can be present.
In the desire realm and the summit of existence, at most only nineteen can be present, because all lack three applications of mindfulness.
The reduction in the others should be considered according to the stage.
Why is the mind king not established as a factor of enlightenment?
It is also included in the applications of mindfulness, etc., because it actually includes all preparatory wholesome [dharmas].

However, it is not established separately like discernment, etc. The mind is impartial in the defiled and pure parts, with equal power and function, without partiality. The factors of enlightenment are only in the pure part, with stronger power and function. Therefore, they are not established.
Other masters say:

The factors of enlightenment mostly take the common characteristics of dharmas as objects. The mind king mostly takes its own characteristics as objects and arises. Therefore, they are not established.
Other masters say:

Cultivating the factors of enlightenment is originally for countering all afflictions. However, the afflictions are mental factors, not mind. Therefore, the counteractive factors are not only mental. This is because the counteracted and counteracting are established by mutual opposition.
Some say: The factors of enlightenment assist enlightenment. Enlightenment is a mental factor, because its essence is discernment.
It is not possible for the mind king to assist mental factors, just as it is not possible for a king to assist his ministers. Therefore, the mind king is not established as a factor of enlightenment.
Other masters say:

The mind guides the world in the transmigration of the three realms, five destinies, and four forms of birth, and it is never exhausted. One cultivates the factors of enlightenment in order to end birth and death. For this reason, the mind king is not established as a factor of enlightenment.
Other masters say:

Since beginningless time, the mind has been defiled by many afflictions and has scattered to various objects, being intractable and difficult to tame. One cultivates the factors of enlightenment in order to tame the mind. That which is to be tamed is not the same as that which can tame. For this reason, the mind king is not established as a factor of enlightenment.
Why, among the many mental factors, are only four established as factors of enlightenment?
In reality, they are all included within the foundations of mindfulness, etc., because they all include the wholesome of added effort.
However, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom are established separately, because these three strongly assist the pure factors and can be established as factors of enlightenment.
Conceptualization, volition, contact, and desire strongly assist the defiled factors, and therefore they are not established separately.

In the contemplation of imagination, the power of resolve increases, and the factors of enlightenment are only included in the contemplation that accords with reality. For this reason, resolve is not included among the factors of enlightenment.
Other masters say:
When one reaches the stage of post-learning, resolve increases. The sÅ«tras only establish it as a factor of post-learning.

The factors of enlightenment increase in the stage of learning. For this reason, they are able to give rise to supreme enlightenment. Therefore, resolve is not included among the factors of enlightenment.

The power of attention can move the mind and cause it to easily change and be unstable with regard to its object. The factors of enlightenment carefully observe objects and cause the mind to be focused on one thing.
They are contrary to that. Therefore, attention is not included among the factors of enlightenment.
If that is so, why is investigation established as a factor of enlightenment?

Although investigation stimulates the mind with regard to objects, it causes the mind to seek the ultimate truth, not to be unstable and easily change with regard to objects. It has the ability to stimulate observation of the truths. It is said that this power stimulates right view. For this reason, attention cannot be compared to investigation.
Other masters say:
If defiled or pure, when first apprehending an object, the power of attention is increased and is said to be unreasonable.

When attention in accordance with principle continues to the object, its power is weak, and therefore it is not established as a part of the defilements or enlightenment. The parts of the defilements and enlightenment must increase in the state of continuing with regard to the object.
Because feeling increases in both the defiled and pure categories, it is established as a part of enlightenment.

For this reason, in the nidÄna of transmigration and causation, it is established as the nidÄna of feeling, and in the category of enlightenment in cessation, it is established as the part of enlightenment of joy.
Other masters say:

Although feeling is a dominant condition in defilement, it also has the ability to benefit the pure category, just as a caá¹‡á¸Äla, although of low class by nature, can do beneficial things for the nobility. Therefore, in meditative absorption, it is a beneficial category, and in the category of enlightenment, it is established as a part of enlightenment.
Why are the three feelings all associated with the pure path, and is only joy a part of enlightenment, not the other two?
The aspects of the factors of enlightenment are extremely sharp, while the aspects of pleasure and indifference are slow and dull and therefore are not established as factors of enlightenment.
Other masters say:
The two feelings of pleasure and indifference are the pleasure of serenity,
but the aspect of indifference is covered by the feeling of indifference and is not clear.
Therefore it is not established as a factor of enlightenment.
Why, among the dharmas that are mental activities associated with the great ground of wholesome dharmas,
are only four dharmas established as factors of enlightenment?
In reality, they are all included in the foundations of mindfulness, etc., because they are all included in the wholesome of added effort.
However, faith, effort, serenity, and indifference are established separately because these four are strong in assisting enlightenment.
How is it that these four are strong in assisting enlightenment?

Faith is foremost in initiating the quest for enlightenment. In preparing to cultivate various practices, faith is the initial foundation. The cause and effect of purity take faith as their basis. If one has no faith, cultivation and practice will not succeed. Therefore the faculty of faith is established as a factor of enlightenment.
Other masters say:
Just as a clear water gem placed in muddy water causes the water to become clear and pure, enabling those with eyes to discern various forms,

In this way, faith, which is placed among the factors of the class of mind, can cause the class of mind that is born with it to become clear and pure. Because of this, one can see the principle of the four noble truths, which gradually increase and grow, becoming the three kinds of enlightenment. Therefore, faith should be established as a factor of enlightenment.
Vigor universally stimulates all practices, causing them to quickly proceed to the enlightenment of the three vehicles.

If there were no right effort, even if one has already set out, one will become lax and indolent in the middle and will never accomplish anything. Therefore, vigor is established as a factor of enlightenment.

Other masters say:ğŸ”½The reason why one is not able to see the four noble truths from beginningless time is entirely due to indolence and lack of delight in listening to and properly contemplating the principle of the four noble truths.

Vigor can cure that and cause one to delight in listening to and properly contemplating the principle of the four truths. Therefore, one can see the four truths and quickly realize enlightenment. Therefore, vigor should also be established as a factor of enlightenment.
Tranquility and equanimity are established as members of enlightenment because they increase the supramundane path and cause one to quickly enter the bodhi of the three vehicles.
Other masters say:
From beginningless time, the mind has been disturbed by torpor and agitation, and one does not see the truth of reality. Because of this, one does not realize the bodhi of the three vehicles.
Tranquility eliminates torpor, and equanimity stops agitation. Because of this, one sees the truth and quickly enters bodhi. Therefore, these should also be established as members of enlightenment.
If that is so, then the intrinsic nature of shame and conscience is good, and they are included in the category of good dharmas. They should also be established as factors of bodhi.

They should not be established, because shamelessness and lack of conscience are only associated with all evil minds. They are the most obstructive to scattered precepts, and their power to obstruct seeing the truth of reality is slight.

Shame and conscience are the opposite of these two, and are included among the intrinsically good dharmas. Even though they have a superior power with regard to the precepts of personal morality, their power as aids to good in samÄdhi is slight. The factors of enlightenment are selected in accordance with their aid to good in samÄdhi and their assistance in arousing the principle of the truths. Therefore the two are not established as factors of enlightenment.
If this is so, then you should establish noncraving and nonhatred as roots of goodness, because they are intrinsically good.
They also should not be established as such, because craving and hatred are associated with the six consciousnesses, are found in all five stages, and are the seeds of the passions.
They generate coarse evil actions as superior added efforts, and they obstruct the good of personal morality, but their power to obstruct the vision of the truths is slight.

Noncraving and nonhatred are established as roots of goodness because they are the opposites of these two, because they are intrinsically good, and because they are included among the intrinsically good dharmas. Even though they have a strong power with regard to good actions of personal morality, their power as aids to good in samÄdhi is slight. The factors of enlightenment are selected in accordance with their aid to good in samÄdhi and their assistance in arousing the principle of the truths. Therefore they are not established as factors of enlightenment.

If this is so, then nonnegligence should be established as a member of enlightenment, because of nonnegligence all practices are accomplished, and the Buddha always exhorts one to cultivate nonnegligence.

It should also not be established, because in a state of distraction, negligence causes the mind to run and scatter to the five desires, and it is powerful in obstructing the use of the good of charity, etc., and it is not the most powerful obstruction in a state of concentration.
It is established as nonnegligence in order to oppose it.

It only guards the mind in regard to the five desires, causing it not to run and scatter, and it is specialized in the cultivation of charity, etc. Therefore, although its power and function are strong in regard to the good of distraction, its power and function are slight in the good of concentration. The factors of enlightenment take that which accords with the good of concentration and assists in understanding the truth of the path. Therefore, they are not established.
If this is so, then nonharming should be established as a member of enlightenment, because it is able to oppose harm.
It should also not be established, because harm arises in regard to events and obstructs the cultivation of the good of distraction by afflicting sentient beings.
Non-harming is the opposite of this, and its power of assisting samÄdhi is slight, and therefore it also should not be established as a factor of enlightenment.
Other masters say:
Among the greatly virtuous dharmas, those whose objects of counteraction are strong and whose natures are superior are established as factors of enlightenment, and the others are not.
Those whose objects of counteraction are strong are associated with all defiled minds.
Those whose natures are superior assist the view of the truths.ğŸ”½As was said above, faith, effort, pliancy, and equanimity are endowed with both meanings. Shame, etc., are not endowed with both.
The five of shame, etc., are not endowed with both meanings.
Non-negligence is of one kind and lacks only the superior nature.
Why are joy and disgust not factors of enlightenment?
In principle, they are also included in the applications of mindfulness, etc., because they really generally include preparatory good dharmas.

However, they are not established separately as factors of enlightenment, because the aspects of these two are mutually contradictory, and they do not universally take the four noble truths as objects. There is no single stage in which they are always present, and the class of mind is small. For this reason, they are not established.
Other masters say:

The power of wisdom observing objects causes joy and disgust. The members of enlightenment are said to be able to assist the arising of wisdom. Since their meanings are contradictory, they should not be established separately.
Why is it that both applied thought and sustained thought are capable of being good as preparatory, and also pure, yet one is a member of enlightenment and the other is not?
In reality, both are capable of it, but the meaning is as explained above.

However, applied thought is established separately and sustained thought is not. Applied thought is strong in stimulating right insight in the holy path, because when it arises, its mode of activity is fierce and sharp, and it assists insight in seeking the truth. It is established as a member of the path.
Sustained thought is not like this, because its mode of activity is extremely weak when it arises.
Other masters say:

When both are present, the mode of activity of applied thought is coarse and obscures sustained thought. When only sustained thought is present, the mode of activity evolves to be subtle. Therefore sustained thought is not established separately as a member of enlightenment.
Since right effort already exists in stimulating right insight, why is applied thought established as a member of enlightenment?

Since right view and right thought are different, they should both be established as members of the path. Right view is established as a member of the path because it is the forerunner of the path, while right thought is established as a member of the path because it is the cause of right speech, action, and livelihood.
Why is it that the path does not establish the act of volition as a member of the path?

The members of the path are only good dharmas that conform to samÄdhi. The noninformative that accompanies mind has a superior ability to conform to samÄdhi, but the act of volition does not. Therefore it is not established as a member of the path.
Why does the path not establish the dissociated dharmas as members of the path?
They have no special power to assist in awakening, because they are not associated with mind.
Unlike noninformative action, which, although not associated with mind, has the function of an axle in the wheel of the path. Therefore it is not established as a member of the path.
Other masters say that
the two mindless samÄdhis are able to extinguish mind and therefore are in opposition to awakening.
The four characteristics and acquisition have the function of causing the conditioned to move and be produced. They function equally in regard to impure and pure dharmas.
The members of the path function to assist in purification, and therefore they are not established separately.
Why are faith, etc., not established as members of enlightenment and members of the path?

When one first sets out on the path, faith is predominant. Once one has entered the holy paths, enlightenment and the members of the path are established. At that time, the power of faith is weak and therefore it is not established as a member of enlightenment or a member of the path.
Why are joy, pliancy, and equanimity established as members of enlightenment, but not also established as members of the path?
Because they are biased in favor of enlightenment and not in favor of the path.
How are they biased in favor of enlightenment?

In the path of cultivation, each stage cultivates nine grades of superior enlightenment. As one repeatedly awakens to the truth, one gives rise to superior joy. Because of the arising of superior joy, one delights in contemplating the truth again. It is like a person who digs the ground and obtains treasure, giving rise to joy. Because of the arising of joy, one delights in digging again. Therefore joy increases in power in accordance with enlightenment.

One must rely on pliancy to rest from all activities, and because of the power of equanimity, the mind becomes equal, and only then can one carefully investigate and perceive objects. Therefore pliancy and equanimity are established as members of enlightenment.
How do these three not accord with the path?
The meaning of the noble path is rapid progress, and these slightly contradict rapid progress, because they can both cause the mind to abide in peace.
Why is investigation established as a factor of the path but not also in the factors of enlightenment?
Because it only accords with the path, not with enlightenment.
How does it accord with the path?

Moreover, in the path of seeing, investigation spurs right view, causing it to quickly observe the eight truths above and below. Precepts are like the hub, forming the wheel of the path of seeing, causing it to quickly turn in the truths. Therefore, both investigation and precepts are established as factors of the path.
How does this not accord with enlightenment?
Moreover, investigation does not turn in a tranquil manner regarding the truths, because its characteristic is to investigate the principle of the noble truths.
Enlightenment turns in a tranquil manner after seeing the truths, therefore investigation slightly contradicts enlightenment.

The seven factors of enlightenment are associated with thought, have objects, have supports, and have activities. Precepts are the opposite of this, and therefore they are not established as factors of enlightenment.
The name â€œpathâ€ means universal progress, and it cannot be used as an example.
